SALARY REVISION FOR THE ADMINISTRATIVE, PROFESSIONAL,
AND OTHER SERVICES
(Statement by the Minister for Trade and Industry)


     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has accepted the recommendation of the Committee on Scholarships and Civil Service Careers to revise salaries in the Administrative, Professional and Other Services.

Justification for Salary Revision

    The need to revise salaries is most acute in the Administrative Service. This Service is a key national institution. Administrative Officers formulate and implement Government policies under the direction of the political leadership, to protect the security of Singapore, promote economic growth, and ensure the well-being of our people.

Column: 379

The standards of ability, integrity and commitment expected of Administrative Officers are high. The most outstanding have to be as good as the best in the private sector. The Service must therefore always attract and retain its share of the top talent in Singapore.

State of the Administrative Service

    Over the last 20 years, the Government has been able to identify and develop a core of young, able administrators to succeed the older generation of Permanent Secretaries (PSs). However, we have not succeeded in maintaining this flow of talent into the Civil Service. Our talent pool is inadequate for proper succession planning. Unless we correct this situation early, the quality of the Civil Service which we have painstakingly built up will decline.

     Reliance on Scholars. The Administrative Service depends heavily for talent on returned scholars who went to university on Government scholarships. But in recent years this source has dwindled. More able students are refusing Government scholarships. Whereas a generation ago a Public Service Commission (PSC) scholarship was the only way for many talented students from poor families to go to university, nowadays many parents can easily pay for their children to attend NUS, NTI, or even overseas universities. Not enough top students are applying for PSC scholarships to meet the public sector's expanded needs.

     Declining Recruitment and Strength. Annual recruitment in the Administrative Service has declined steadily from a peak of 37 in 1974 to an average of less than 10 per year in recent years. The number of non-scholars joining the Service has fallen even more drastically. In 1974, there were 23. They represented 62% of the intake. Two-thirds were non-scholars. Since 1980, we have had not more than one non-scholar per year. In some years, none. There is no queue of qualified applicants seeking to join the Administrative Service.

Column: 380



    Many of those within the Service have left as soon as their bonds have expired, and some even sooner. Every one of those who were recruited in 1975 and 1976 has left. So have three-quarters of the 1977 and 1978 cohorts, and half of the 1983 cohort. As the economy boomed after the 1985 recession, able young officers quit for more attractive jobs elsewhere. The strength of the Service has fallen steadily. Here I refer you to Annex A (Cols. 467 - 468). From a peak in 1975 of 260 officers, it has declined to 183 this year, down by 30%. Important public sector jobs remain unfilled for lack of suitable Administrative Officers.
Annex A - NUMBER OF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS AS AT 1ST JANUARY OF EACH YEAR, 1974-1989 (Cols. 467 - 468)


Salary Comparisons with the Private Sector

    Many of those who have resigned have complained, among other things, that promotions came too little and too late. The most successful of those who left the Service are earning 40% to 100% more than their contemporaries who stayed. In order to qualify to join the Administrative Service, a person must be practically in the top 30 in his year, in terms of performance. Then he will get an Overseas Merit scholarship, and has a chance of being absorbed into the Administrative Service. Or if he did not take a scholarship, he has to be of the same calibre: top 30. Annex B (Cols. 469 - 470) shows that in every age group below the age of 40, the most outstanding of the Administrative Officers is earning less than about 150 other persons of the same age in the private sector. This is a very complicated chart, Mr Speaker, but the dotted lines show how much the top earners of each age group are earning. The 1P line means the most well off person of that age. You can see the most successful person in Singapore is aged 39. He earned $2.6 million, one person. Those may be aberrations. So look at the 10th most successful person in an age group: the 10P successful person in an age group: the 10P line. Their incomes peak around the age of 40-41, about $350,000 a year. Similarly, for the 25th person, and the 100th person. The bottom line on the chart is the most successful Administrative Officer. That is the line called AS/A (Administrative Service/ Actual). He is earning well below the

Column: 381

100th person around $150,000. I will come back to this chart later. The Administrative Service has lagged far behind the private sector in remuneration.
Annex B - COMPARISON OF PRINCIPAL INCOME OF TOP EARNERS IN THE ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE AND PRIVATE SECTOR BY AGE (Cols. 469 - 470)


    There is another way to make this comparison with the private sector, and that is, to look at the top earners, profession by profession. Look at Annex C (Cols. 471 - 472). This is the average monthly income in 1987 of the top man, the second man and the third man in some of the big companies in a range of businesses. It is an average of three, four or five companies, showing how much their top three people are earning. They represent typical rather than maximum earnings. A typical top banker earns $141,000 a month. His second in command earns about $31,000 and the third earns $22,000. In comparison, the single most successful banker earns $197,000 a month in 1987. If we take sharebrokers, $122,000; lawyers, $102,000; multi-nationals, $64,000; even local companies, $50,000. The Prime Minister released a similar table in 1983, when we discussed Ministerial salaries in this House during the Budget debate. You will see from this table that most of the numbers are several times larger than the gross salary of a substantive Permanent Secretary, Grade C, whose monthly salary all-in, including NWC, is $16,000. The car dealer earns nearly twice as much.
Annex C - AVERAGE 1987 MONTHLY INCOME OF THE TOP THREE EXECUTIVES IN A SELECTION OF LARGE SINGAPORE COMPANIES AND PROFESSIONAL FIRMS (Cols. 471 - 472)


Need for Salary Revision

    A Civil Service career offers certain traditional advantages over the private sector more stable incomes, stability of tenure, plus significant pension benefits for those in the pensionable services. The Civil Service therefore need not match, dollar for dollar, the very highest incomes in the private sector.

    However, the free-market outcome proves conclusively that these positive factors do not compensate for the wide disparity between public and private sector incomes. Capable young men and women are no longer attracted by these traditional advantages. In a full employment economy, there are jobs everywhere. No bright young man believes that he will

Column: 382

ever have difficulty finding a job. Civil Service pensions may be expensive to the Treasury, but that does not make them attractive to young people, more attractive than the full CPF contributions which every other job carries. The value of a pension is uncertain, especially for an officer near the beginning of his career, because the pension will only be collected somewhere in the very distant future, and it is indexed to the cost of living, unlike pensions for British civil servants. In other words, you are not sure when you will get it, and you are not sure what it will be worth when do you get it.

    Young people are under no pressure to accept PSC scholarships, and see no reason to do public service at a personal sacrifice. Able civil servants are opting out and they are not being replaced fast enough. Low salaries and slow advancement are major factors in low recruitment and high resignation rates. A substantial salary rise for the key individuals in the public sector, especially the Administrative Service and related services, is therefore essential.

Principal Considerations for Revision

    This salary revision package reflects five principal considerations. Firstly, as a fundamental philosophy, the Government will pay civil servants market rates for their abilities and responsibilities. It will offer whatever salaries are necessary to attract and to retain the talent that it needs. As the Minister for Finance stated in his Budget Speech, the Government can afford to do so, and this is only being fair to the officers concerned.

    Secondly, the salary revision must be consistent with the principles of wage reform. We should not simply increase basic salaries. Timescales should be shortened. Remuneration should vary with the state of the economy, and individual rewards should depend on each person's own performance.

    Thirdly, the revision must be selective, and not across the board. Salaries are not revised as a status symbol, or as a reflection of the worth of the service. They are

Column: 383

revised only when officers are paid too little relative to the market. Civil Service relativities should not be ignored, but they cannot cause us to increase salaries across the board when the problems are more specific.

    In this exercise, the first priority for salary revision is the Administrative Service. This service has the most acute problem and needs the largest adjustments, followed by the Professional Services. The Government recognizes that some other services also face structural problems, but the Committee will examine them later.

    Fourthly, this revision is not a routine annual salary adjustment. It is designed to catch up with several years of rising private sector incomes, and to make public service careers more competitive with the private sector. The revision should not be taken as a benchmark for the National Wages Council deliberations, or for other salary negotiations in the private sector this year.

    Fifthly, and finally, this exercise, including other salary changes to selected services which my Committee is still studying, will be the definitive salary revision for the Civil Service this year. The adjustment to the CPF rate, which is due in July, naturally will also apply to the Civil Service. However, the Government does not intend to make any further salary changes after the NWC recommendations are published. We cannot have two bites of the apple in quick succession.

    These five principles apply to the whole Civil Service. For the purpose of this salary revision, the Government has divided the Civil Service into three groups:

    First, the Administrative Service and the other pensionable services.

    Second, the Professional and related services, and

    Third, the rest of the Civil Service, including the daily rated employees.

Structure of Administrative Service Salary Package

    Firstly, for the Administrative Service specifically, the Government has decided to do the following:

Column: 384



    (a) We will increase basic salaries by 7% for the superscales, and by 13% to 20% for the Timescales;

    (b) We will increase the existing end-of-year non-pensionable Variable Bonus by (r) month;

    (c) We will introduce a new discretionary performance-based bonus of up to 2 months of salary for Superscale officers alone, in order to relate benefits to individual performance; and

    (d) We will speed up promotions, so that benefits will be commensurate with the potential of individual officers.

Basic Salary Revision

    Because of the size of the gap between private and public sector salaries, some revision of basic salaries is necessary. Annex D (Cols. 473 - 474) shows the revised salary scales. First, the Timescales, Administrative Assistant, Senior Administrative Assistant, Assistant Secretary, PAS. Then on the next page, the Superscales, G, F, E and so on. You will notice that the Timescales have been shortened and the ratio of the top to bottom salaries in each scale has also been reduced. For the Administrative Assistant, the first and longest scale with 14 points, originally had a ratio of about 2.4 top to bottom. Now it is a ratio of about 1.4. Similarly, the later scales have also been shortened. For the Superscales, there is a straightforward 7% revision.
Annex D - NEW ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE SALARY SCALES (Cols. 473 - 474)


    The percentage revision for Timescales is larger than for the Superscales, for several reasons. Timescales will not be included in the performance bonus scheme. Many officers are resigning long before they reach Superscale grades. Competitive salaries at the entry point and early in the career are important for retaining them, and also for attracting other graduates who did not receive scholarships and are not already bonded to the Government.

New Staff Grades

    Besides increasing the basic salaries of existing Superscale grades by 7%, the Government is also creating two new Staff Grades, Grades IV and V (you can see them at the bottom of the page) to

Column: 385

increase the maximum salary point of civil servants.

    The upper Civil Service grades and the salaries of Judges and Ministers are linked. For example, Judges are paid superscale A, and Ministers are paid Staff Grade I + 5%, It is expressed in terms of the Civil Service grade points. A top civil servant who reaches Staff Grade III (there is nobody in that grade now, but the grade exists) will earn more than any Minister except the Prime Minister. The Government will be revising the salaries of Ministers and Judges. We will be pegging these political salaries to higher grade points to leave more room for promoting civil servants. The new Staff Grades IV and V will maintain the relativity between the apex of the Civil Service pay structure and the salaries of political appointees.

    At Staff Grade V an officer will receive a gross salary of $42,000 a month (including NWC). Compared to the private sector earnings of top executives, particularly Annex C, this is modest, not excessive. Those promoted to these new staff grades will be the most outstanding officers, particularly those holding extremely large and probably multiple job responsibilities. The Public Service Commission does not envisage promoting anyone to these new grades in the near future. It will be several years before any officers reach Staff Grade IV or V. Nevertheless, the real likelihood of attaining these higher grades is important for the morale of serving officers, and for attracting outstanding young people to join the Service.

    Members will notice that the new salaries are expressed in terms of basic pay. We have not mentioned NWC. In previous pay revisions, the Government consolidated NWC awards accumulated over the years into the basic salary, which meant they were locked in and became pensionable. The NWC awards after the last salary revision in April 1982 have not been consolidated. There are three of them: the 1982, 1983, 1984 awards. 1985 was a recession. There was nothing. 1986 wage restraint, nothing. 1987 was partial restoration. 1988 restoration but no new award. 1982, NWC awards are part 1983 and 1984 of the variable component of the salary, and they can be reduced in bad

Column: 386

years. Therefore, they will not be consolidated in this exercise.

Higher Variable Bonus

    The second component for the Civil Service is the Higher Variable Bonus. We have implemented flexible wages in the Civil Service by introducing a year-end variable bonus which depends on the state of the economy. So far, we have built up this variable bonus to reach months of salary. Part of the salary adjustment should go towards increasing this variable bonus. The Government will raise it by (r) month, bringing it to 1ª months in all, provided that the economy grows this year by 5 - 8% as expected. This (r) month is equal to a 4% increase in the basic pay, but with one important difference: whether it is paid depends on the state of the economy.

    Instead of paying the entire variable bonus in December, the Government will pay (r) month of the bonus in July and the remaining month in December. If by the end of the year economic growth turns out to be less than 5%, then, of course, this balance of 3/4 month will have to be reduced.

New Performance Bonus

    Thirdly, the performance bonus. Rewards should vary not only with the state of the economy, but also with the performance of each individual. The Civil Service should move away from a non-discriminatory egalitarian system of rewards, based on the fiction that every officer is as good and productive as every other officer, to a system which ties rewards with performance, and singles out the outstanding from the rest. Performance bonuses will make the salary scheme more flexible, and give Permanent Secretaries an additional instrument for rewarding good officers.

    The Government will introduce an annual, discretionary, non-pensionable performance bonus of up to two months of salary, based on individual performance, for Superscale officers in the Administrative Service. The Head of the Civil Service will consult the Permanent Secretaries and put up proposals to the PSC for endorsement. In other words, the Permanent

Column: 387

Secretaries will discuss who should receive how much bonus. The Head of the Civil Service will put their recommendations to the PSC, the PSC will endorse. Actual bonus payments will be kept strictly confidential.

    Not everyone will receive the full two months of bonus. Only a small proportion of officers, the obviously outstanding ones, will. Another 20% to 25% of the above average officers will be paid 1(r) months. The bulk of the officers will receive a one month bonus. 5-15%, those who are under-performing or clearly below average, will receive no performance bonus. These groupings correspond to natural breaks in the performance ranking of officers. Although we state that two months is the maximum, we expect only 5-10% of officers to receive two months. Those who are well above average, in the top one-quarter or so of the population, you get 1(r) months. An average Superscale officer gets 1 month. A below-average Superscale officer, and you notice that I have put it as 5-15%, the lower bound is greater than zero, gets none.

    For this performance bonus scheme to work, the assessors will have to be rigorous and strict in ranking the performance of officers against their peers. They have to rank officers against their peers, to decide who is average, who is good, who is bad. Officers must have the courage to identify the outstanding, the above average, and the under-performers. If they take the soft way out and claim that nearly everyone is above average, then the scheme will fail. To prevent this, quotas will be set for each category of officers. In other words, Permanent Secretaries have to be hard and firm. They must have the courage to decide between two officers who is better, who is not so good, and recommend one for an above average bonus and another perhaps for nothing. And having done that, they must have the courage to face the officer and say, "This was my honest and well-considered judgment of you and I consider it fair." If we do not do that, the scheme will fail.

Column: 388



Faster Promotion

    Faster promotions are as important a factor in retaining good officers as higher salaries. Promotions are a much more selective and discriminating method of rewarding good officers than salary increases. They give deserving officers a sense of forward movement in their careers, and show that the organization values their contributions, which an equally generous salary scale will not do.

    In the Civil Service, how quickly an officer is promoted depends on several things. Firstly, what we call his CEP (Currently Estimated Potential). Secondly, on the time norms for promoting officers with that potential. The CEP of an officer is formally assessed by panels of Permanent Secretaries and their deputies. For every Administrative Officer, we judge him, we assess him, we evaluated his powers of analysis, his powers of imagination, his sense of reality, his helicopter qualities and we make an assessment of how high he can go. He may be a junior Assistant Secretary, but you already know that he can one day become a Permanent Secretary. He may be a Deputy Secretary, Grade E, but you know that he has reached the ceiling grade and he is unlikely to go further, even though perhaps he is doing well in that grade. That is the CEP. Having worked out the CEP for each individual, we have tables to define for each class of persons this is your potential, this is the rate at which you will be promoted.

    Despite all this apparatus, in the last few years, promotions in the Administrative Service have been slow, for a combination of reasons. Permanent Secretaries have been conservative in assessing the CEPs of officers, our time norms for promotions have been a little slow, and even these norms have not always been followed, particularly in the lower grades. As a result, officers, particularly the young ones, feel a sense of frustration. They want out to go somewhere where they can move fast.

    To speed up promotions, the Government has shortened the promotion time norms. Generally, officers will be promoted to their final ranks by the age of 45 instead of 50. All intermediate promotion

Column: 389

points will be brought forward accordingly. If you must reach Grade C by the age of 45, then when do you reach Grade D, Grade E, Grade F, Superscale all that is worked out. Able officers should reach the rank of PAS (Principal Assistant Secretary) two years earlier than at present, by the age of 30, within eight years of joining the service, a crucial milestone, because it is around that time that their scholarship bonds expire. Such an early promotion to PAS will be a clear signal to an officer that he is doing well.

    At the senior levels, the Government will no longer treat every Permanent Secretary post equally as a Grade C post, just like every other one. It will recognize that the PSs of larger ministries, and the CEOs of the major statutory boards, are Grade B, Grade A, or even Staff Grade posts. For example, the Head of the Civil Service is obviously a Staff Grade post. If the Head of the Civil Service is not Staff Grade, who would be? These establishment ranks will make it clear that Grade C is not the practical ceiling for Administrative Officers. All high flying helicopters look out and watch the cloud base and wonder whether they can go through. So this is to show the sun shining through the clouds.

     An hon. Member: It is raining.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: It is not raining. These establishment ranks will provide reference points for assessing the potential of very able officers, and make it easier to assign them accurate potentials above the Grade C, and therefore to promote them faster. We have officers who could be Permanent Secretaries of big ministries or who could run large statutory boards like PUB or PSA or HDB, but because we only say he is Permanent Secretary, we assess his CEP at Grade C, and promote him at Grade C rates. He arrives at Grade C at the age of 50. He may have left by the age of 50. So with this, if we can judge, by the time a man is in his mid-30s, that he can be a CEO of HDB, for example, or Vice-Chancellor of NUS, then we say, "All right. That is equivalent to a Grade A post, we move him at that rate." I give these only as examples.

    These faster promotions are an integral part of this plan to make the Administra-

Column: 390

tive Service more attractive. The Government could have packaged an equally attractive proposal comprising larger across the board salary increases alone, without speeding up promotion rates, but it would have been an inferior solution. Of course, not every officer expects to be promoted in this exercise, nor should an officer be promoted automatically because he happens to be occupying a post with an establishment rank which is higher than his rank. Otherwise the element of selectivity is lost. But overall promotion rates have to change if we are to achieve the full purpose of this exercise.

Views of the Public Service Commission

    The Public Service Commission is responsible for promotions of officers. The Government has consulted PSC on these proposals. The Commission agrees with the salary adjustments and agrees with the concepts proposed to effect these adjustments. It also agrees that the changes will help to improve the Administrative Service.

Impact of Proposed Changes

    These revisions will have a major impact on the attractiveness of the Administrative Service. I refer Members back to Annex B and also to Annex E. Annex E (Cols. 475 - 476) shows how the fastest moving Administrative Officer whose potential is Grade A will compare with his private sector counterparts as he progresses up the Civil Service ladder. The left-hand side shows the existing position and actual fastest movement. The right-hand side shows the planned ranks and the planned movements. At present, nobody has moved all the way to Grade A. The furthest a person has gone, according to the present promotion norms, is PS Grade C, age 44, where he ranks 24th in his cohort. Along the way there, as you can see, he is sitting well below the 100th mark. I said 150, but in fact, in his early 30s, they rank around 250. This is in comparison with 1987, mind you - 1989 Administrative salaries agains 1987 private sector salaries. So if we compare against 1989 private salaries, the position is even worse.     In the private sector, most multi-national companies conduct annual surveys of salaries and benefits to ensure that they are paying the market rate. For those who want the best, they pay a premium.

Column: 444

subsidy and increase the subsidy for the rest of the student population? I hope the Minister for Finance is here but he is not around. Yes, the Minister of State for Finance is around. He should be listening. Because the Minister for Finance said that education is an investment.

Column: 445

CPF projections. This will help to allay uncertainty in financial planning of their parents.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, increases in fees are never popular and the increase in

Column: 448

fees by NUS and NTI announced last week has predictably drawn a number of comments from Members of Parliament both today and on Monday and also from members of the public, in particular the university students.

    Most of the comments have focused on the quantum of the increase and the worry that the increased fees will impose hardship on students. I think this is entirely understandable and I sympathize with much of the sentiment. I shall address this matter later on in my statement this afternoon. However, in my view, Sir, the comments have not really addressed the nub of the issue. The increase in fees is not the result of an ad hoc decision by NUS and NTI. the increase in fees is a consequence of a policy decision made by Government. The central issue, Sir, is how should university education be financed? Should it be entirely or almost entirely through a Government grant financed through taxpayers' money, or should it be through a mixture of Government grant, direct fees paid by students, and student loans? Let me give a little background to this issue.

    In Singapore, as in many other countries in the Commonwealth, including England, Australia, Canada, New Zealand where some of our students go to, the traditional method of financing university education has been through a Government grant, and the fees paid by students are consequently nominal. This system has its obvious attractions, particularly for students. We would have liked to continue this system, and the system was workable so long as the cost of operating universities was not high.

    However, Sir, today, with the cost of running universities being a major item in the education budgets of most countries, the system of financing university education entirely through grants from the Government is coming under strain. I do not have to point out to Members the financing problems which many universities today in England, Australia, Canada and New Zealand are facing. Some universities in those countries have expressed a fear that because of inadequate finance they have to run the risk of lowering the quality of education provided

Column: 449

to their students. For example, by not filling up academic posts when these fall vacant or by not upgrading their facilities and equipment even when this is necessary. There is no shortage of reports in the daily press on how the universities in these countries are now today, finding that their grant from the respective Governments to be inadequate to run their universities properly.

    Let me just quote a few examples which I have taken at random from the Times Higher Education Supplement. The first one, Sir, is from the 17th February 1989, and it is headlined "Principals' gloom and anger over pay". I will just read a few paragraphs. This is a statement by Sir David Smith, the principal of Edinburgh University and he warned:

    'The time is fast approaching when it will be impossible to run good universities on the present system of funding (ie through a Government grant). In a bleak address to the University's General Council, Sir David Smith, the principal of Edinburgh University, says that he sees little prospect of improvement in the overwhelming problem of the university's financial position. Student/staff ratios will inevitably rise. The provision of services such as libraries will decline in quality and the discontent of the staff which is chronically underfunded will continue.'

    Another article, Sir, from the same Supplement, 21st October 1988, headlined "Faculties' defiance as cuts loom".

    'The English Department at Lancaster University in England has accused the University of putting financial constraints over academic quality in its drive to cut cost.

    The third one, Sir, 12th August 1988, from a different country, Australia. "Australian students to be taxed as from 1989."

    'Australia's 400,000 higher education students will pay a tuition tax of A$1,800 for each year of study from the start of 1989.'

    This is for Australian students. For foreign students who are studying in Australia, as Members will know, they have to pay the full-course fees which is very much higher than the A$1,800. I will not bore Members with these articles but just one more, which I like very much: "Universities declare war on Ontario Budget". I just quote the first paragraph, Sir.

Column: 450



    'The Ontario Council of Universities frustrated by what it describes as a decade of chronic underfunding has declared war on the provincial government [that is Ontario] 1989/90 budget.'

    I think, Sir, these examples will, I hope, suffice to show that the traditional system of funding universities entirely from the Government with students paying only nominal fees cannot continue. In Singapore here, Sir, we have established two tertiary institutions, NUS and NTI. We can be proud of them. They are recognized to be of international standards. But if we want NUS and NTI to operate properly, we must give them adequate finance, not too lavishly, but enough for them to run their operations properly as universities, and this means a lot of money $351 million for the financial year 1989/90 for the operating cost alone, ie, the recurrent expenditure without taking into account their development costs. The major part of this expenditure, Sir, must inevitably be financed by a grant from the Government. But the question we should ask ourselves is: should Government finance all, or almost all, of the expenditure of NUS and NTI?

    In this connection, Sir, the Member for Ayer Rajah has referred to some figures which I quoted in 1987. I have updated the figures and I will ask the Clerk of Parliament to distribute the table now. These are the figures for the distribution of expenditure among our various educational sectors for the financial year 1988. If Members will study the table, they will see that for FY 88/89 NUS and NTI have a total student population of some 20,600 students - about 18,600 undergraduate students and about 2,000 post-graduate students. These 20,600 students comprise 4% of the total student population of 523,000 students in Singapore. The remaining 503,000 students are in our schools, junior colleges, technical institutions, Pre-U centres and VITB. But in terms of Government expenditure on education, however, this 4% of students studying at the university accounted for 19% of the total recurrent Government expenditure on education in 1988/89. The remaining 81% was spent on educating over 500,000 students in our schools, junior colleges, pre-university centres and other technical institutions. In other words, last year, on the average, the

Column: 451

Government was spending over $13,000 each year to educate a student at the university level as against $2,300 for each student in our schools, junior colleges, pre-university centres, polytechnics and the VITB.

    Now, Sir, the Government regards education as an investment in people and we have funded education generously. But the disparity between the allocations is such that it must be more equitably distributed among the various educational sectors in Singapore and I think that it is right that we should reduce, as I have said in 1987, the percentage of Government expenditure on education that is allocated to the universities so that we may have more money to spend on upgrading the quality of education in our schools and the other sectors of education in Singapore where the majority of our students and pupils are. This sets out the fundamental principle why it is necessary to raise university fees.

    I now come to the actual fee increase. In raising university fees, we must always keep one basic principle in mind and, that is, we must make sure that students who come from poor families, whether these are Singaporeans or non-Singaporeans, should not be penalized or prevented from acquiring a university education simply because their parents cannot afford to pay the fees. This is a basic principle which we must follow in all fee increases. But it is because we want to ensure that access to university education is not dependent on the students' financial circumstances that the Government in 1987 earmarked a sum of $100 million to be operated as a revolving fund to finance loans to students and these loans are for a specific purpose of helping NUS and NTI students to meet the cost of their university fees.

    I would like to inform Members of the number of students who have actually applied for these loans and the amount of the loans. For the academic year 1988/89, 3,174 students from NUS and NTI applied for the Government loan schemes. These students comprise 17% of the total undergraduate student population of 18,600 at

Column: 452

NUS and NTI. The total amount that was borrowed was $4.5 million or an average of $1,400 per loan. In this connection, Sir, I just read in today's Straits Times a letter in the Forum page with the rather alarming headline "Indebted graduates will be hard-pressed to repay debts". I had, in fact, asked the NUS and NTI to work out how many years a student would need to repay the student loan from the Government after he or she graduates and Members may find some of these figures to be of interest.

    Let me take, for example, a Singapore student who is studying a course in Arts or one of the non-laboratory based disciplines. Assuming that the student takes the full 50% tuition loan, ie, $1,300 out of the new fees of $2,600. Then for the three-year general degree course, his total loan will be $3,900. If he gets Honours, that means an additional year, the total loan would be $5,200. Assuming the student passes his examinations and graduates and then joins the Government and he uses, say, 10% of his starting salary to repay the loan. The calculation shows that he will be able to repay the amount of money which he owes to the Government well within four years. This is not taking into account any salary increases which the student may get during the period of the first four or five years of his working life, nor the salary increase which was announced this morning.

    Similarly for a student who is taking a laboratory-based discipline like engineering or science and working on the same basis, the number of years which the student will require to repay the loan is just over four years. It is less than five years. For a student who is studying medicine, the period is just over eight years. Since the terms of the student loan allow the student as long as 15 years to repay his loan, one can see that the claim that indebted students will be hard-pressed to repay their debts is not borne out by the facts.

    Sir, in the university's press statement, it is also stated very clearly that if the Government loan scheme is not sufficient, students can apply to NUS and NTI for additional loans from the universities' own

Column: 453

loan funds. For 1988 and 1989 the number of students at NUS and NTI who applied for this additional financial assistance was 300, less than 2% of the student population of 18,600 students. Of those who applied, over 90% were granted additional financial assistance by NUS and NTI. The total amount approved by the universities was $219,000 with the average grant being just under $1,000. These figures show quite clearly that through the Government loan scheme and the universities' own funds, there are more than ample resources to ensure that no student who enrols or who is currently studying at NUS or NTI would be prevented from continuing his education simply because he is unable to find the ready cash to pay his fees. In fact, Sir, to our knowledge, no student has ever left the NUS and NTI on account of financial circumstances. He may leave because of other reasons, but not because he cannot find the means to pay his fees.

    What I have said, Sir, applies just as much to non-Singapore students as to Singapore students. I may add that such generous provision of student loans to foreign students is unheard of in other countries. The reason for us being so generous is that we recognize the importance of having foreign students in our universities. They enable our own students to have a broader and richer university education interacting with students from other countries and with different cultures. It is pertinent to note that, even with the increased fees, the fees for non-Singapore students studying at NUS and NTI are between half and one-third of the corresponding fees which a foreign student would have to pay to study at universities in Australia, England, New Zealand or America. As I have just said, Sir, the loan schemes which we have made available for Singapore students, ie, the 50% tuition loan scheme from the Government and the universities' own additional loans, are not confined to Singapore students. The schemes are open to non-Singapore students as well. I hope therefore, that non-Singapore students would not be deterred from applying to study at NUS and NTI. If they are bright enough to be accepted by our universities, we will ensure, as for Singa-

Column: 454

pore students, that they will be given sufficient financial assistance to enable them to study here.

    In this connection, Sir, I want to refer to a point made by the Member for Tampines GRC, Dr Aline Wong, on Monday concerning the $2,000 limit on loans granted by the universities from their own loan funds. Sir, I am happy to inform her that the universities exercise discretion with respect to this $2,000 limit. They will waive the limit where necessary for students in needy circumstances. The Member can set her mind at ease that the limit will not be an obstacle to a student who needs additional funds.

    As to the point brought up by the Member for Leng Kee regarding the timing of the announcement, the fee increases have had to be decided after the Finance Ministry has settled its budget for the year and we have to announce the fees before students apply for the new session. It is only fair. We cannot announce the fees after they have applied and then find that they have to pay new fees. So this is the reason why the new fees have to be announced during this period.

    To sum up, Sir, university students are educated at very large public expense. They can aspire to highly remunerative jobs and to earn good salaries when they graduate. After receiving the benefit of a university education, it is only right, Sir, that when they are working they should pay back part of the Government's subsidy in order to lessen the burden of financing university education purely through taxpayers' money. After the recent fee increases, the grant by Government will finance about 77% of the operating expenditure of NUS and NTI.

    As a long-term target, NUS and NTI should work towards steadily reducing the percentage of their operating expenditure which is financed by Government to somewhere between 60% and 70%. But, of course, this cannot be done immediately and it will have to be implemented over a period of time in order not to place an undue burden or hardship on students and their parents. At every stage we must ensure that the fee increases do not have the effect of limiting access to NUS and

Column: 455

NTI, particularly for students who are bright but who come from poor homes. These students have as much right to university education as children whose parents are in more comfortable circumstances.

    In a nutshell, Sir, the policy of the Government is and will continue to be to make sure that no bright student who has been accepted by NUS or NTI will be preventd from acquiring a university education simply because his or her parents cannot afford to pay the fees and we will do what is needed to maintain this policy, including, if necessary, reviewing our loan schemes or providing other forms of financial assistance, such as awarding more scholarships or bursaries if this is shown to be necessary.

We will do so through moral education and by promoting the use of the mother tongue, by strengthening the teaching of values in schools [and so on.]'

    In the Addendum to the President's Address, the Minister for Education said:

    'The inculcation of core values must begin in the home. The values can be reinforced in the primary schools by ensuring adequate proficiency in the

Column: 456

mother-tongue, and through appropriate lessons in the Social Studies, Moral Education and Extra-Curricular programmes.'

    Sir, one of the questions that come to my mind is: how are the core values to be taught in schools? I am referring to the medium for the teaching and learning of these core values - English or mother tongue? My personal view is that it should be taught in the mother tongue. While there is no denying that we can always learn something from the experience and experiments of others, I hope that the superficial impressions formed from glimpses of two homogeneous societies will not be the basis on which Singapore's core values are formulated.

    Singapore is a multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious society, quite different in composition from Taiwan and Hong Kong. It is obvious that the core values which should be taught in our schools

Column: 457

must serve the objectives of promoting social cohesiveness and developing a Singaporean identity out of the diverse groups of Singaporeans. That these must be essentially Asian is axiomatic. They must also be values which uphold the three most dearly held Asian institutions of family, community and country, besides the values which promote self-development. I hope that in its eagerness to draw up a core values progrmame, the Ministry of Education does not go about it the wrong way.

    There are certain values that we cherish in Singapore and which have served us well. They have sustained us through turbulent times. Otherwise, we would not have survived and prospered as a nation. These are the values that we must identify, preserve and teach our young.

    One challenge that is facing us is to put up a creditable team of experts who will not only be able to identify and prioritize the values we have, but also arrange for their introduction into our schools. Another challenge is to provide a definition of core values that transcends ethnic differences, reconciles incompatabilities and encompasses a universal outlook.

    I will venture to suggest that in its search for core values, the Ministry should first look at its own backyard. Over the years we have had a whole host of values education programmes, from Education for Living and Good Citizenship to Being and Becoming and Religious Knowledge. I am sure that the Ministry will find a wealth of materials and information in its own archives.

    Our problem has been that we have always relegated values education to an unimportant, secondary position in our school curriculum. The answer is not only to make the teaching of core values merely a subject in the school time-table, but also to make our core values a part of the ethos of every school community. The inculcation of core values, if they are to have a life-long effect, must be internalized in each child. In order to achieve this, our core values education programme must build upon the real life examples and experiences that children can see, practise and understand.

Column: 458



    The teaching of the values must not only be formal but also pervasive, otherwise it will sound like shallow moralizing and will lack the ring of authenticity. These values must permeate the school system and be reflected in its organizational structure, its daily transactions and routines, the way staff and pupils are dealt with, the school rules, and the manner in which critical situations which will arise from time to time are handled. These values, to be effective, must constitute the school's ethos, its beliefs and its practices.

A value system only begins to function when there is a community of believers subscribing to it. However, if there exists only a superficial acknowledgment of the system, it is destined to fail. People who lack conviction will not reflect the value system in their daily conduct. What will become apparent mo all then is the existence of a double standard - do as I say but not as I do. Hypocrisy of this kind will neutralize all attempts to promote the system.

    These are warning signposts that I would like to set up along with the accolades of moral values.

ment? Who will give us that assurance that future governments will not use Confucius' teachings once it is established here for their own benefit?

And they have recommended that the Religious Knowledge programme be reassessed, implying that if the undesirable consequences outweigh the desirable ones, then the programme should be dropped. The recommendation of the Report was based on several observations. First, Singapore, being a secular state, should keep religion and state separate. When religious courses are introduced into all schools, this principle of separation between state and religion is actually being breached. Second, in deciding on which religious courses to be taught as options in the RK programme, the Government is officially endorsing the chosen religions over the others.     Sir, I believe the observations of the Report deserve our serious attention. And I agree that a close look at the RK programme should be made. A decision on its continuation should be taken sometime in the future.

    RK was introduced as part of the Moral Education programme in 1984. The rationale behind its introduction was our concern that younger Singaporeans have become "deculturised". To counter this trend, emphasis is placed on teaching traditional values so that young Singaporeans can identify with their own cultural roots. We may have to drop the courses no matter how good the original intention was and how much resources we have poured into the programme already.

    Let me now turn to the subject of pre-primary classes. On 29th January 1989, the papers carried a report on the Auditor-General's recommendation that the pre-primary programme should be scrapped. Pre-primary classes have become very popular with parents because of the longer hours and the lower fees as compared with kindergartens. Also, the classes provide a Mandarin-speaking environment, a more structured programme and better-trained teachers. It is therefore understandable that parents are quite disappointed by the Auditor-General's recommendation, especially since it seems to place so much emphasis on the cost factor.

    I believe cost-effectiveness should not be the main criterion for the Ministry to take a decision on the matter. Instead, we should address two fundamental questions: First, is it the function of the Ministry of Education to provide pre-primary education? If not, what other alternatives are open to parents? Second, has the pre-primary programme served to give children a headstart in learning Chinese?
